thread.title: Here’s how many people could lose Obamacare coverage in your district - South Florida Business Journal
thread.title_full: Here’s how many people could lose Obamacare coverage in your district - South Florida Business Journal

author: Nina Lincoff
title: Here’s how many people could lose Obamacare coverage in your district - South Florida Business Journal
text: Here’s how many people could lose Obamacare coverage in your district Feb 21, 2017, 1:49pm EST Updated Feb 21, 2017, 1:59pm EST Industries & Tags Nina Lincoff Reporter South Florida Business Journal Share Nina Lincoff Reporter South Florida Business Journal Related Content 28 photos If the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare, is repealed without a comprehensive replacement almost 630,000 people living in the U.S. congressional districts that make up South Florida, are expected to lose coverage, according to a recent analysis. Nationwide, between 20 million to 30 million people may lose their health insurance, according to the analysis by Charles Gaba , a Michigan-based healthcare analyst and owner of acasignups.net . Gaba looked at congressional districts across the U.S. and estimated how many people are expected to lose coverage in the event of a full repeal with no replacement. 28 photos There are 27 congressional districts in Florida, and nine of those include parts of South Florida. In those nine districts, almost 840,000 people enrolled on the ACA health care exchanges for coverage in 2017 as of Jan. 31. The South Florida districts make up nine of the ten in Florida that would see the greatest loss of coverage. In one district, the analysis estimates that as many as 81,549 people may lose coverage. Click through the slideshow to see how many people may lost coverage in districts across Florida. Across the entire state, more than 1.76 million Floridians were enrolled in health care coverage on the exchanges as of Jan. 31. Approximately 1.3 million of those enrollees are projected to lose coverage in the event of a repeal. The Trump administration has been very much against the ACA, and P resident Donald J. Trump has said that he plans to "repeal and replace" Obamacare . Nina Lincoff covers banking, finance, insurance and investments. Get the latest banking news with our free daily newsletter. Click here to subscribe. Related Content
